statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

article.description: Baron Davis scored a career-high 38 points as the Charlotte Hornets held on to beat the Detroit Pistons 104-96 Wednesday night.
article.headline: Davis scores career-high 38 in Hornets' win

images.name: Davis, Baron 011128 inline
images.caption: A familiar sight Wednesday night: Baron Davis driving to the basket.

article.linkText: Pistons grab record-low 18 rebounds in loss to Hornets
article.story:
AUBURN HILLS, Mich. (AP) -- P.J. Brown looked up in disbelief. Had the Charlotte forward actually outrebound the entire Detroit Pistons team in the Hornets' 104-96 victory Tuesday night? Yes, P.J. you did. Detroit set an NBA record with just 18 rebounds, the lowest total in league history. "I've been playing basketball for about 20 years," said Brown, who grabbed 17 defensive rebounds for a total of 20, "and I've never even heard of something like that in my life." Baron Davis' career-high 38 points were overshadowed somewhat by Detroit's lackluster rebounding effort. The Pistons had one fewer rebound than Seattle did when it set the previous NBA record with 19 rebounds against Phoenix in 1999. "We're not proud of that," Detroit coach Rick Carlisle said. Charlotte coach Paul Silas wasn't too interesting in reflecting on the record. "We've got to see them Friday," Silas said. "I'm not going to say a word." The Hornets never trailed and appeared to be cruising to an easy victory with a 23-point third-quarter lead, but Detroit pulled to 85-82 with six minutes left. Charlotte made just enough shots and stops to prevent the Pistons from getting any closer. Detroit's Ben Wallace, who was second in the NBA in rebounding last year, grabbed nine rebounds -- three times more than any of his teammates. "We may have only had 18 rebounds, but we were still in the game," Wallace said. "You just can't dig yourself a hole like we did and expect to win. That's the bottom line." Davis made 15 of 20 shots -- inside, outside and off-balance -- and didn't cool off much after scoring 16 in the opening quarter. "I was in a nice rhythm," Davis said. "It felt good. It makes you want to shoot more, but you have to be conscious of the clock, your teammates and getting good shots." Davis' backcourt mate, David Wesley, scored 20 points. Brown had 12 points and Lee Nailon added 10 points. Silas said the team is waiting for Jamal Mashburn to get the results of a second opinion and to decide whether he will need surgery to correct the abdominal strain that has kept him out of the last five games. Detroit's Jerry Stackhouse, who missed the previous three games with a strained groin, scored 26 points. "I felt pretty good for the most part," Stackhouse said. "But I'm hurting now." Reserve Chucky Atkins scored a season-high 25 points and played a big role in the Pistons' comeback. Cliff Robinson added 18 points, but had just one rebound in 43 minutes. Davis scored 12 points within the first six minutes and was 7-for-7 for 16 points in the first quarter as Charlotte led 26-16. Wesley scored 10 points in the second to help the Hornets build a 53-32 halftime lead. Stackhouse capped a 13-3 run with a 3-pointer late in the third to pull Detroit within four points, but then Charlotte outscored Detroit 9-1 to end the quarter and take a 73-61 lead. Davis entered the fourth shooting 13-for-17 for 31 points. "What a performance," Carlisle said. "He's really developed into a fantastic player. He was sensational and we're going to have to figure out a way to stop him on Friday." Davis' previous career-high was 33 points set on opening night against Cleveland. Game notes
Detroit's Dana Barros left the game early in the first quarter with a pulled left hamstring. ... Charlotte has won two straight while Detroit had won two in a row. ... The Hornets have won four consecutive at Detroit, but have lost three in a row at home against the Pistons. ... The Pistons made nine 3-pointers in the second half, which tied a team record for 3-pointers in a half.
